awd_titl_txt: SBIR Phase I:  Robotic vertical glass sorter powered by machine vision and artificial intelligence for accurate, accessible, sustainable, and cost-effective glass recycling
awd_abstract_narration:
The broader impact of this Small Business Innovation Research (SBIR) Phase I project will address the over 10 million metric tons of glass disposed of annually in the U.S. While 100% of glass is recyclable, only 33% is actually recycled, as it is challenging to sorting and transport used glass prior to recycling. Traditional methods for these key functions dramatically reduce the value of the glass due to transportation costs and required warehouse space for sorting glass from other waste and separate the colors of clear, brown, and green. Even modern U.S. glass sorting facilities require warehouse space of more than 250,000 square feet for horizontal runway and belt systems to clean and sort waste streams well enough for an automated glass sorter to continue. This leads to high costs, manual labor, negative environmental impact for the machines, and high levels of glass that is not recycled. The proposed project advances a robotic system to sort efficiently. 

This Small Business Innovation Research Phase I project will target a prototype hopper and actuator control system, AI engine for detection and sorting, and field performance study.  The main development challenges include enhancing the camera and sensor network of the prototype platform; developing and validating an AI engine for rapid classification of falling glass; and developing actuator controls, and system integration and functional testing to specifications. First, the prototype will be enhanced including the mechanical design, material flow, sensor network, and actuators for the sorting mechanisms. Next, using prerecorded videos of falling glass and waste under different conditions, an AI engine will be developed and validated to accurately classify glass colors and trigger an actuator sequence.  Once algorithms have been validated offline, the hardware and algorithms will be integrated at a system level and validated for performance in real-time operation.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
OPTISort team is dedicated to sustainability and is making great progress, especially towards glass sustainability using AI and machine learning. Every piece of glass that's accurately sorted, every resource that's efficiently recycled, adds to the company's legacy of positive environmental impact.

 

Urgent and Growing Need for Sustainability:

As nations, communities, and individuals become increasingly aware of the environmental challenges ahead, the demand for sustainable solutions is skyrocketing. This product will tap into this burgeoning market. Its adaptability will cater to diverse recycling needs, from small municipal recycling facilities to expansive industrial setups.

 

Project Sustainability Impact:

Beyond the technical aspects and research, the project promises a broader, more profound impact on society and the environment. Efficient recycling is a logistical challenge as well as an environmental imperative. In a world grappling with the consequences of waste and the challenges of sustainability, solutions like OPTISort are urgently needed.

 

Technical/Research Outcome:

The OPTISort initiative represents a great stride in the world of glass recycling. By combining machine vision with the artificial intelligence, the dedicated team behind this project has created a robotic glass sorter of unparalleled capability.

 

The journey of OPTISort's development was marked by rigorous research, iterative design, and meticulous testing. The machine's algorithms, fine-tuned through countless hours of data analysis, demonstrated an impressive accuracy rate.

 Future Plans:

Our team will be working with municipal recycling facilities and bottle/fiber glass manufactures to evaluate the output in field conditions.  Our interview with the industry players has confirmed an urgent and massive need for recycled glass.

 

By championing efficient and eco-friendly glass recycling, OPTISort contributes to a significant reduction in environmental waste. Every shard of glass that's accurately sorted and recycled is a step away from landfills and a step closer to a sustainable ecosystem. The technology's impressive accuracy ensures that resources, once discarded, are given a new lease of life, contributing to a circular economy that values reuse and sustainability.
